evidence.detectionMethod: Sequencing of all exons of CACNA1C
evidence.previousTestingDescription: clinically relevant LQTS genes - see group info

dc:source.dc:abstract: Gain-of-function mutations in CACNA1C, encoding the L-type Ca(2+) channel Cav1.2, cause Timothy syndrome (TS), a multi-systemic disorder with dysmorphic features, long-QT syndrome (LQTS) and autism spectrum disorders. TS patients have heterozygous mutations (G402S and G406R) located in the alternatively spliced exon 8, causing a gain-of-function by reduced voltage-dependence of inactivation. Screening 540 unrelated patients with non-syndromic forms of LQTS, we identified six functional relevant CACNA1C mutations in different regions of the channel. All these mutations caused a gain-of-function combining different mechanisms, including changes in current amplitude, rate of inactivation and voltage-dependence of activation or inactivation, similar as in TS. Computer simulations support the theory that the novel CACNA1C mutations prolong action potential duration. We conclude that genotype-negative LQTS patients should be investigated for mutations in CACNA1C, as a gain-of-function in Cav1.2 is likely to cause LQTS and only specific and rare mutations, i.e. in exon 8, cause the multi-systemic TS.
dc:source.dc:creator: Wemhöner K
dc:source.dc:title: Gain-of-function mutations in the calcium channel CACNA1C (Cav1.2) cause non-syndromic long-QT but not Timothy syndrome.

evidence.detectionMethod: Complete sequencing of CACNA1C gene completed
evidence.previousTestingDescription: clinically relevant LQTS genes tested (see group info)
Commercially available LQTS genetic testing panel

dc:source.dc:abstract: Long QT syndrome (LQTS) is the most common cardiac channelopathy with 15 elucidated LQTS-susceptibility genes. Approximately 20% of LQTS cases remain genetically elusive.
dc:source.dc:creator: Boczek NJ
dc:source.dc:title: Exome sequencing and systems biology converge to identify novel mutations in the L-type calcium channel, CACNA1C, linked to autosomal dominant long QT syndrome.

evidence.rdfs:label: III-1

evidence.detectionMethod:
PCR and sequencing conditions were carried out using standard protocols (information is
available on request).
evidence.previousTestingDescription:
A subset of the LQTS cohort of 540 unrelated patients was completely sequenced
for the main LQTS genes, namely LQT1–8 [15]. In addition, in a stepwise approach 710 unrelated LQTS patients were analyzed for LQT gene mutations in the LQT1–13 subforms. Overall, the complete CACNA1C gene was analyzed in 540 probands

evidence.detectionMethod: Comprehensive open reading frame and splice junction mutational analysis of the entire coding region (57 amplicons that encode 2139 amino acids) of CACNA1C.
evidence.previousTestingDescription: Clinically available LQTS panel available through commercial laboratory.
evidence.rdfs:label: Case No. 4

evidence.detectionMethod: Gene screening was performed using high-resolution melting (HRM)12 or denaturing high-performance liquid chromatography (dHPLC;WAVE system Model 3500; Transgenomic) and subsequent direct sequencing,
evidence.previousTestingDescription: KCNQ1, KCNH2, SCN5A, KCNE1, KCNE2, and KCNJ2.

dc:source.dc:abstract: CACNA1C mutations have been reported to cause LQTS type 8 (LQT8; Timothy syndrome), which exhibits severe phenotypes, although the frequency of patients with LQT8 exhibiting only QT prolongation is unknown. This study aimed to elucidate the frequency of CACNA1C mutations in patients with long QT syndrome (LQTS), except those with Timothy syndrome and investigate phenotypic variants.
dc:source.dc:creator: Fukuyama M
dc:source.dc:title: Long QT syndrome type 8: novel CACNA1C mutations causing QT prolongation and variant phenotypes.

direct sequencing.

evidence.dc:description:
The current densities of cells transfected with CACNA1C-R858Hwere significantly larger than those of WT.
Compared with WT(open circles), peak inward current densities were significantly larger in R858H (squares) at potentials between 210 and +30 mV, with a maximum of 52% increase
at +10 mV (251.5+8.8 vs. 278.3+6.6 pA/pF, P , 0.05).
Activation of R858H channels showed an 2 mV negative shift compared withWT. In contrast, inactivation of A582D and R858H channels showed an 2 mV positive shift. Thus,
both R858H and A582D mutations exerted gain-of-function effects, and eventually their window currents were larger than those of the WT.
evidence.rdfs:label: Channel activity

evidence.dc:description:
Different experiments demonstrate GOF for different variants.
Peak current amplitudes were increased for A28T, I1166T and I1166V.
While wild-type Cav1.2 channels reach their peak current maximum at about +20 mV (green trace), I1475M and E1496K mutants showed a leftward shifted peak current potential, with maximal inward currents at+10 mV (red traces).
Correcting for the shift in the voltage-dependence of the different LQT mutants, only E1496K has a strong change in inactivation kinetics. The slowed inactivation for E1496K is expected to cause a gain-of-function and thus might contribute to prolonged action potential duration.
While I1166T had a pronounced reduction in steady-state inactivation the
voltage-dependence of inactivation for this mutation and for I1166V, I1475M and E1496K was not shifted. In contrast, A28T and R860G displayed a rightward shift in the voltage-dependence of inactivation reflecting a gain-of-function.
evidence.rdfs:label: Voltage-dependent current

evidence.dc:description:
Functional characterization of the mutation using whole-cell patch clamp technique in a heterologous HEK293 expression system revealed a gain-of-function phenotype
with a 113% increase in peak ICa,L at +10 mV compared with WT.
evidence.rdfs:label: Patch-clamp

dc:description:
CACNA1C encodes for the alpha-1c subunit of the voltage-dependent L-type calcium channel which is important for the development of the action potential in human cardiomyocytes. Pathogenic variants in CACNA1C are the cause for Timothy Syndrome, a rare multi-organ disorder whose manifestations include QT prolongation and ventricular arrhythmias (PMID 15454078). Boczek at al. were the first to identify a variant in CACNA1C in a family with genotype-negative cardiac-specific typical LQTS (PMID 23677916). They performed exome sequencing of 3 members of the family and filtered the shared genetic variants identified using bioinformatics tools. Several other studies have provided additional genetic and experimental evidence to support the association of CACNA1C with typical LQTS, however, no segregation or case-control data is available and the overall level of evidence for this association was classified by the Working Group as moderate.
Note: All LQTS genes were curated by 3 separate blinded teams. The evidence and scores reached by these 3 teams was reviewed by the LQTS Clinical Domain Working Group. The classification and summary presented here is the conclusion of this Working Group's analysis according to evidence available at time of publication. The scores presented here are the result of only one of the three curation teams' efforts. For a detailed discussion of this group's work and the scores of all 3 teams please see "Adler et al. An International, Multicentered, Evidence-Based Reappraisal of Genes Reported to Cause Congenital Long QT Syndrome. Circulation 2020;141(6):418-428. doi: 10.1161/CIRCULATIONAHA.119.043132”
